title: Government extends public consultation period on Voluntary Health Insurance Scheme
content_text:
p>
	The Government today (March 14) announced that the public consultation 
	exercise on Voluntary Health Insurance Scheme (VHIS) will be extended for 
	one month to April 16 to allow the public to have more time to express their 
	views on the Government's relevant proposal. A spokesman for the Food and Health Bureau said, "Since the launch of the 
	public consultation exercise on December 15, 2014, the Government has 
	organised or attended nearly 70 consultation sessions and public forums to

organised or attended nearly 70 consultation sessions and public forums to 
	gauge views from the relevant sectors and the public. As of yesterday (March 
	13), the Government had received more than 270 submissions. "According to the views we have received so far, the public in general 
	support the VHIS but have concerns over certain areas, such as premium 
	increase after the implementation of the scheme, the service capacity and 
	manpower of private hospitals to cope with a possible increase in demand for 
	service in the future. There are also views expressing reservations over the

service in the future. There are also views expressing reservations over the 
	benefit coverage under the scheme. "As the VHIS is a supplementary financing option to facilitate the healthy 
	development of the healthcare system, as well as an important measure to 
	adjust the balance of the public and private healthcare sectors, we hope the 
	public can actively give their opinions during the extended consultation 
	period to help us formulate a health insurance scheme that meets public 
	needs." The VHIS proposes to regulate individual indemnity hospital insurance 
	products. Following the implementation of the scheme, all individual

products. Following the implementation of the scheme, all individual 
	indemnity hospital insurance products must comply with the Minimum 
	Requirements prescribed by the Government to ensure that products purchased 
	by consumers offer value for money. Insurers must offer to consumers a 
	Standard Plan that meets all 12 Minimum Requirements as an available option, 
	so as to enhance the accessibility and continuity of hospital insurance, as 
	well as the quality and transparency of hospital insurance.
